awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Energetics of Secondary-Active Glutamate Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
The plasma membrane separates the interior of the cell from the extracellular space and provides a barrier to cell entry/exit for many molecules (for example nutrient or signaling molecules) that are essential for cell survival. Glutamate is one such molecule, which is not only an amino acid needed for the synthesis of proteins, but also the most important neurotransmitter in the mammalian brain, responsible for the majority of excitatory neurotransmission. Glutamate is transported across the plasma membrane through active glutamate transporters, which play essential roles in controlling the levels of glutamate in the mammalian brain and other tissue. This project explores the fundamental principles by which these transporters work. Understanding these principles is important because it will contribute to our knowledge not only of the role of glutamate and nutrient movement between cellular compartments in the mammalian brain, as well as other organs of the body, but also glutamate homeostasis, which is important for cellular function in general. Furthermore, the developed methods for analyzing transport will be applicable to potential future studies of other neurotransmitter and/or nutrient transporters and membrane proteins. On the educational level, the project provides an invaluable opportunity for undergraduate students to become involved in cutting-edge biophysical research, providing training in basic physical, quantitative approaches to be applied to a significant biological problem. The investigator is continuing previous efforts of undergraduate involvement (including members of under-represented groups), which has led to many publications with undergraduate students as co-authors, as well as students successfully moving on to careers in research. The investigator is also very active in local and regional activities that promote the sciences at all levels, including demonstrations at schools, science fair involvement, and assuming leadership roles in the local American Chemical Society (ACS) section and the Science Olympiad. Such activities are necessary to ensure a vibrant local science community and to foster excitement of the upcoming generations of young scientists for science and research. 

Active glutamate transport is a multi-step process that requires multiple ion/substrate binding steps, as well as conformational changes. Despite recent progress towards understanding the transport process through functional studies, as well as the identification of structural models of a bacterial homologue of mammalian glutamate transporters in several states, basic questions about the mechanism, specificity, and dynamics of interaction of the transporters with cations, in particular K+ and Li+, as well as the energetic contributions to energy barriers that control the transport rate and specific structural changes in the transport cycle remain unresolved. Answers to these questions are obtained by applying a combination of experimental and computational methods, allowing the investigation of the dynamics of glutamate transport in real time, with microsecond time resolution, and to test predictions from all-atom and simplified molecular models. This work has the potential to reveal new aspects of glutamate movement across the cellular membrane, in particular with respect to the cooperation of polar and non-polar forces, which are fine tuned to adjust the energy barriers associated with ion/substrate binding, as well as conformational changes. The novel insight may uncover more general concepts that are employed by membrane transport proteins, in order to provide a permeation pathway for polar molecules across the hydrophobic membrane.

por.por_cntn:
Our work funded by the NSF award 1515028 has provided further insight into the molecular mechanism of glutamate transport across cellular membranes, an area of research that the Grewer laboratory has pursued for more than 20 years.  Glutamate transporters are transmembrane proteins that take up glutamate from the extracellular space into cells against a concentration gradient, thus contributing to the homeostasis of the amino acid glutamate in the mammalian brain and other tissues.  These transporters are thought to be involved in several diseases and conditions, for example stroke, Alzheimer's disease etc. Therefore, identifying the mechanism of glutamate transport, and its structural and energetic basis, is important for our understanding of these patho-physiological states.  In particular, our activities have focused on several major gaps in knowledge that existed before the start of the funding period. 

One of those gaps in knowledge was the mechanism of substrate and inhibitor binding to glutamate transporters.  In two major publications in the Journal of Biological Chemistry and ACS Chem. Biol. (2016 and 2019), we have discovered that substrate and inhibitor binding to the transporter occurs within the electric field of the cell membrane, by performing analysis of the speed of transport, together with computational modeling.  The results of those studies have implications for our understanding how the membrane voltage modulates transporter behavior and function.   

Second, glutamate transporters allow the passage of anions across the membrane.  Along these lines, we have identified the mechanism of anion interaction with glutamate transporters, providing evidence for a novel anion conducting state, in which sodium and potassium must be bound together in order to allow anion movement through the transporter.  This work was published in the Journal of Biological Chemistry in 2019.

Third, we have obtained detailed insight into the mechanism of glutamate translocation (the actual process of glutamate movement across the membrane) by analyzing the electrostatics of the translocation pathway, using computational methods together with experimental testing.  We found that the electrostatic barrier, which has to be overcome during translocation, is reasonably small only when at least two sodium ions are bound, consistent with a charge compensation mechanism. This work was published in J. Phys. Chem., 2018.

Fourth, our work has led to the development of a novel method to rapidly screen glutamate transporter function using fluorescent methods, including the ability to simultaneously measure currents and fluorescence changes in single cells.  This method will provide a straightforward and rapid way to screen blockers of glutamate transport, for potential pharmaceutical applications.  This new method was published in ACS Sensors in 2019.

Finally, we have contributed to several other projects in collaborations, resulting in four publications.  Overall, the work on glutamate transporters and other projects in the cumulative funding period has led to 11 peer-reviewed publications and a manuscript in preparation.  Furthermore, five posters were presented by graduate students at national and regional meetings    

In addition to the research activities that were funded through this proposal (Scientific Merit), the Grewer laboratory was involved in mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as a significant number of outreach activities, with the objective to foster interest in the sciences and to train the next generation of scientists, a pre-requisite of sustaining a modern workforce (Broader Impacts). 

Along these lines, the PI has directed the Southern Tier of New York Science Olympiad twice at Binghamton University. In addition, he has served as Program Chair of the 2016 ACS Northeastern Regional Meeting, in Binghamton, NY, has contributed to the Freshman Research Immersion Program in Biomedical Chemistry at Binghamton University, which provides original research experience for undergraduate students at the freshman level, and he has trained a total of ten undergraduate students in cutting edge research and scientific methods. Three of these students have co-authored a publication.  Overall, this NSF award has facilitated the continued involvement of the Grewer laboratory in training and outreach activities at many levels in the scientific community.
